title: Search
description: Search allows users to enter a keyword or phrase and get relevant information. Itâ€™s an alternative to other forms of navigation.

contentChunks.htmlValue: The search bar is a prominent way for people to navigate a product through search queries. Search view, which displays dynamic suggestions, is the open active state of search bar.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Search bar
2. Search view

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposePlanned
FlutterIn progress
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Selecting the search bar and entering text can display dynamic suggested keywords or phrases
  • Even if the interaction begins with a search bar, results are always shown in a search view to ensure adequite space for results
  • Search bars include a leading Search icon and can also include an optional trailing icon
What's new

• New component for search navigation
  • Full M3 capabilities including dynamic color

Search bar color mapping

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents

Usage
Anatomy
Search bar
Search view

contentChunks.footer: Search bar.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage
Search is a navigation method that allows people to quickly find information across an app. Users input a query into the search bar or text field of the search view and then see related results.

contentChunks.footer: Search bar with a leading and trailing icons.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Search view, which can display dynamic suggestions, is the focused state of search bar.

  1. Search bar
  2. Search view

contentChunks.footer: Search view opens once the search bar is focused.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy
Search bar

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
  2. Leading icon button
  3. Supporting text
  4. Avatar or trailing icon (optional)

contentChunks.htmlValue: Search view

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
  2. Header
  3. Leading icon button\
  4. Supporting text
  5. Trailing icon button
  6. Input text
  7. Divider

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

The container holds all other component elements. The search bar container has rounded corners. The search view container is full screen on mobile.

contentChunks.footer: Search bar and search view containers.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icons and icon buttons

Leading icon
The left side of the bar should contain either a navigational action (such as a menu or up-arrow) or a non-functional search icon.

contentChunks.footer: Search bar containing a non-functional search icon.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Trailing icon
Up to two action icons can be located on the barâ€™s right-hand side. These actions can represent additional modes of searching (like voice search), a separate high-level action (such as current location) or an overflow menu.

contentChunks.footer: Use a maximum of two trailing icons.
Combine an avatar only with one additional trailing icon.
The focused search view can show an optional clear icon.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
TextÂ 

Hinted search text
Provided a short description of what the user will be able to search for.

Input text
Once the user starts typing, the hinted search text is replaced with the input text. Â  Â  Â

contentChunks.footer: Search view with a hinted search text on the left and input text on the right.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Suggestions and results
Present suggestions and search results in a compact, organized list.

Consider including avatars or other high priority entities in search results that the user may want to access right away.

contentChunks.footer: Search view before entering input text showing suggestions.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Divider

Dividers can be used to separate groups of related results or suggested queries.

contentChunks.footer: Separate list items into distinct groups using a divider.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Search bar

The search bar is a persistent and prominent search field at the top of the screen.

Use a search bar when search is the primary focus of the app.

contentChunks.footer: Search bar as the primary focus within an application.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement
The search bar is centered and usually at the top of the screen

contentChunks.footer: A prominent placement of search bars helps users to easily find the entry point for their search queries.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout

When scaling layouts consider how the search bar position and alignment should scale.

For most cases it is recommended that the search bar maintains in its layout region and scales in width accordingly. Internal elements are anchored to the left and right as the parent container scales.

Learn more about how to adopt your layout for different screen sizes in our adaptive design article.

contentChunks.footer: Use the search bar close to the content a user will be able to search.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Focus

On focus, the search bar expands into a search view, which can display historical search suggestions.

To release focus from the search box and dismiss search suggestions, the user taps the Up arrow.

contentChunks.footer: Search bar expanding to the search view after being in focus.

contentChunks.htmlValue: While search view is typically displayed after a user taps search bar, search view can also serve as the primary focus state if searching is intended to be the userâ€™s primary action.

contentChunks.footer: Search views can also be used as a standalone destination reached for example via a navigation item in the navigation bar.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Search

A user can type a query or select from a suggestion (if available). Upon pressing Return, the search is submitted.

Search results are displayed below the search bar.

contentChunks.footer: Entering a search query into the search bar.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scroll

Depending on needs, the bar can scroll away with content or remain fixed at the top of the screen.

contentChunks.footer: Search bar scrolling up with the content appears again once a user scrolls back down the content.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Search view

The search view is a full-screen modal typically opened by selecting a search icon.

Use a search view when search is not the primary focus of the app.

contentChunks.footer: A search icon can also be used to expand into the search view.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement
The search view is a full-screen modal on mobile devices, and a modal connected to the search bar on large screen devices.

contentChunks.footer: Search views can be used in a modal configuration like in the example on the left, or in a full-screen configuration on the right which is the default for mobile experiences.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout

When scaling layouts consider how the search bar position and alignment should scale.

On mobile devices the search view should be a full-screen modal, while on larger screen the search view should be a modal connected to the search bar and scale with the search bar width.

Learn more about how to adopt your layout for different screen sizes in ourÂ adaptive design article.

contentChunks.footer: Use a full-screen search view on mobile devices, and switch to a modal search view on larger screens.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior
Appearing
The user taps a search icon (in a top app bar), opening the search view modal.

contentChunks.footer: A search icon expanding into a search view.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Search

As a user types, historical search suggestions can be shown beneath the search bar.

Upon entering a query or choosing a suggestion, pressing Return submits the search.

Results appear below the search bar and scroll beneath it.

contentChunks.footer: Present suggestions and search results in a compact, organized list.

contentChunks.htmlValue: When displaying results, the search text field remains visible, but not in focus. Tapping the Up arrow releases the focus from search, dismisses suggestions and the on-screen keyboard, and returns the toolbar to its original state.

contentChunks.footer: Entering a search query into the search view.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
